Trypsinize and collect cells:
Cell Counting
If using a cell counter, use the average of three measurements to determine the number of cells.
If using a hemocytometer (count the cells in 1,2,3 and 4 squares in both chambers and take the average). cells/ml = average count per square × 104
Total cells = cells/ml × dilution (if used) x total original volume of cell suspension from which sample was taken)
Re-suspend the cells in lysis buffer to obtain a concentration of 107 cells/ml

of each TL:LB dilution in triplicate.

of the
pyruvate concentration to each well.
Aspirate the medium from cell culture vessel, and rinse with PBS. Aspirate the PBS, and add 0.25% trypsin in PBS.
Place the culture vessel in the incubator (4-10 minutes based on cell type), and after the cells detach, add media (containing serum to inactivate the trypsin).

Transfer the cells to a
tube and keep some in an eppendorf tube for cell counting.

is sufficient) carefully using sterile forceps (keep frozen).

Two options for homogenizing tissue
Option 1 - Using bead homogenizer -
a. Place a bead (3-5 mm stainless steel) into the bead homogenizer compatible vial (from step 11b)

Option 2 - Using stator-rotor -
a. Label plastic tubes EtOH and 0.1% DMPC (dimethyl pyrocarbonate) , one set for each sample) for cleaning.
b. Place homogenizer into EtOH for

TECAN spectrophotometer on and set temperature at
.
a. Ensure the sample plate map of the appropriate method is set for the assay.
b. Set-up the protocol for a dynamic
readout at 420 nm and for the appropriate 96 well plate
Prepare 12 pyruvate concentrations using pyruvate and reaction buffer by carefully pipeting into pre-labeled conical tubes
Example of dilutions (can be subject to change based on sample type and amount of buffer needed):

Calculate the amount of pyruvate + reaction buffer dilution needed for the entire assay -
x 3 (triplicate) x (# samples)

Pipette calculated amount +
(to ensure enough is available) into each corresponding 12 well multichannel reservoir- from lowest to highest pyruvate concentration.

Do linear regression for each well (change in absorbance over the 10 minutes) to obtain the slope OD/min. (Note: the TECAN Infinity200M accounts automatically for the
path length. So the measurement is actually OD/min/cm)
Place the 96-well plate in the spectrophotometer and measure immediately.

Once the measurement has completed in
, Calculate a linear regression for each well to obtain the kinetic output slope (OD/min) and determine the correct dilution by identifying the dilution with the most linear slope.

Pipette
of appropriate TL:LB dilution into three rows (technical replicates) and 12 columns (corresponding to the 12 pyruvate dilutions) on the 96 micro well plate.
Note: Ensure that there are no bubbles

Using a
multichannel pipettor, carefully pipette
of each 12 pyruvate dilutions in triplicate; assay immediately.
Note: Ensure that there are no bubbles
Place the 96-well plate in the spectrophotometer and measure immediately.

Once the read has completed in
, click Export to excel and save the file. Eject the plate and clean up

Keep the multi-well reservoir in the
water bath

LDH enzyme ctivity is calculated as uM NADH/min =
OD/min (slope) * Solution Volume in each well (
) / ( volume of sample lysate (
) * e )
where e=extinction coeff=0.00622 uM-1cm-1
Note: take the absolute value of OD/min (omit the negative sign)
Take the average (of the three technical replicates) activity per pyruvate concentration subject to a threshold of Rsq > 0.9

Plot Tissue Activity Michaelis-Menten curve
a. X = Pyruvate Concentration (mM)
b. Y = Average Activity
For simpler linear curve

plot Lineweaver-Burke:
a. X = 1/Pyruvate Concentration
b. Y = 1/Average Activity

Obtain trend-line linear fit in the Excel program and calculate
a. KM = slope / intercept ; [mM]
b. Vmax = 1/ intercept ; uM NADH/min
Use Bradford assay kit (
https://www.thermofisher.com/order/catalog/product/23200#/23200
) to determine protein concentration to express Vmax (LDH activity) in umols NADH/min/mg of protein

description:
Lactate Dehydrogenase is a key cytoplasmic enzyme that confers the observed Warburg effect in tumors. Its a tetrameric protein composed of combinations of one or two isomers. This protein catalyzes the reversible reaction
This reaction is monitored spectrophotometrically by observing the reduction in absorbance of NADH (which is maximal at 420nm) as pyruvate is converted to lactate.
This protocol, details the steps involved in such a calorimetric assay of cells and tissues.
